name: Donald J. Wheeler
background: Dr. Donald J. Wheeler (b. ~1940s) is an American statistician, author, and SPC expert. University of Texas B.A., Southern Methodist University M.S./Ph.D. in Statistics. Taught at University of Tennessee (1970-1982). Deming student/colleague (21 years), Deming Medal (2010), ASA/ASQ Fellow. Authored 20+ books (translated to 5 languages), 1100+ seminars in 17 countries. SPC Press founder.

principles.name: Common vs. Special Cause Variation
principles.description: Common causes: inherent, predictable process noise within natural limits. Special causes: assignable, detectable signals requiring action. Avoid tampering (adjusting for noise).
principles.falsification: When common vs. special cause variation leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Process Behavior Charts (PBCs)
principles.description: XmR charts plotting data vs. empirical 3-sigma limits to distinguish variation types. Rules: beyond limits, runs (7+ one side), trends (7+ inc/dec), etc.
principles.falsification: When process behavior charts (pbcs) leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Rational Subgrouping
principles.description: Subgroups maximize within-group common cause variation, minimize between-group special causes (e.g., consecutive items by time/machine) for accurate limits.
principles.falsification: When rational subgrouping leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Understanding Variation
principles.description: All processes vary predictably until special causes intervene; use data empirically (no normality assumed) to filter noise and act on signals.
principles.falsification: When understanding variation leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
